info.headline: Flood Advisory issued March 25 at 3:25PM EDT until March 26 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The Flood Advisory is extended for the following rivers in North Carolina... French Broad River Near Fletcher affecting Buncombe and Henderson Counties. .Periods of moderate to heavy rain on Wednesday resulted in storm-total accumulations of 3-5 inches, with isolated totals approaching 6 inches, across the upper French Broad River watershed. This heavy rainfall caused significant rises along the upper French Broad River, from Rosman, to Brevard, Blantyre, Horse Shoe, Fletcher, and Avery Creek. The upper French Broad River exceeded Minor Flood Stage near Blantyre and Action/Advisory Stage at Fletcher, causing nuisance to Minor flooding of adjacent low-lying, flood-prone areas including farmland, woodlands, parks, greenways, river-access areas, and a few secondary roads and driveways. The French Broad River is expected to remain out of its banks into Saturday morning, with conditions improving by Saturday afternoon. ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Nuisance flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...French Broad River Near Fletcher. * WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Action/Advisory Stage. The French Broad River has exceeded bankfull at the gauge site. Isolated farmland flooding is beginning across the French Broad River Valley from Etowah downstream to Avery Creek upstream of the gauge site. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:46 PM EDT Friday the stage was 10.5 feet and falling slowly. - The French Broad River at Fletcher crested at 10.60 feet on Friday at 6:15am. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below Action/Advisory Stage Saturday morning and fall to 7.0 feet by Sunday evening. - Action/Advisory Stage is 10.0 feet. - Minor Flood Stage is 13.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp
